identified-content.org: Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery (Saratoga Springs, NY)

abstract.p: Getty Museum in Los Angeles opens two photography exhibits: Voyages and Visions: Early Photographs From the Wilson Family Collection, and Mexico From Empire to Revolution; Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery opens at Skidmore College; double bassist Edgar Meyer and clarinetist David Shifrin are this year's Avery Fisher Prize recipients, awarded in recognition of outstanding achievement and excellence in music; photo; two new works by choreographer Natalie Weir will be presented by Houston Ballet and by American Ballet Theater (M)

block.p: Picture This Image is everything in the two new exhibitions at the Getty Museum in Los Angeles. Opening tomorrow is ''Voyages and Visions: Early Photographs From the Wilson Family Collection,'' which comes hot on the heels of the opening on Saturday of ''Mexico From Empire to Revolution.'' With images from ancient Mayan ruins to views of Maximilian's execution and the violence of the 1910 revolution, ''Mexico,'' through Jan. 21, consists of more than 250 photographs taken from the 1850's to the 1920's. ''Voyages and Visions,'' on view through Feb. 18 and including one of the mammoth plate cameras of the early days of the medium, presents more than 80 photographs that explore how Europe, Africa, Asia and Latin America were depicted from 1839 through the 1850's. Information: (310) 440-7300.

Picture This Image is everything in the two new exhibitions at the Getty Museum in Los Angeles. Opening tomorrow is ''Voyages and Visions: Early Photographs From the Wilson Family Collection,'' which comes hot on the heels of the opening on Saturday of ''Mexico From Empire to Revolution.'' With images from ancient Mayan ruins to views of Maximilian's execution and the violence of the 1910 revolution, ''Mexico,'' through Jan. 21, consists of more than 250 photographs taken from the 1850's to the 1920's. ''Voyages and Visions,'' on view through Feb. 18 and including one of the mammoth plate cameras of the early days of the medium, presents more than 80 photographs that explore how Europe, Africa, Asia and Latin America were depicted from 1839 through the 1850's. Information: (310) 440-7300.

New on Campus Described as the first art museum in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., the new Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery opens on Friday at Skidmore College. The $10.2 million, 39,000-square-foot angular structure was designed by Antoine Predock of Albuquerque and is finished in split-face block, silvery metal and concrete. It houses classrooms, a 150-seat auditorium and Skidmore's permanent collection. The building is intended for exhibitions, public events, lectures, readings and performances. Through Jan. 28 the inaugural exhibitions, ''S.O.S.: Scenes of Sounds'' and ''Vik Muniz,'' explore, respectively, the phenomenon of sound and the work of an innovative photographer. Information: (518) 580-8080.

Winners The double bassist Edgar Meyer and the clarinetist David Shifrin are this year's Avery Fisher Prize recipients. The prizes recognize outstanding achievement and excellence in music. Each musician is to receive an award of $50,000. Among previous recipients are the pianists Murray Perahia, Emanuel Ax and Andre Watts; the cellist Yo-Yo Ma; the clarinetist Richard Stoltzman; and the violinists Elmar Oliveira, Sarah Chang and Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg.

Fleet of Foot For Natalie Weir, the 33-year-old resident choreographer of the Australian Ballet, it's quite a week. From Thursday through Sunday, the Houston Ballet will present the world premiere performances of ''In a Whisper,'' her reflective work for five men and five women dancing to the adagio from Schubert's String Quartet in C. Information: (713) 227-2787. And at City Center on Saturday, the New York premiere of Ms. Weir's ''Jabula,'' a celebration of tribal ritual set to music by Hans Zimmer, will be offered as part of the American Ballet Theater's fall season, which begins with a gala tomorrow and continues through Nov. 5. Information: (212) 477-3030.
